title: Energy Justice by Design: How We Helped The Hague Design Energy Cooperatives That Changed Local Welfare Policies
subtitle: Inside the experiment that tested whether a smart energy cooperative could route its surplus directly to people in need — and the vision of a city-wide social cooperative that ensures energy security and independence for everyone in the green transition
featuredImageAlt: Energy justice experiment design for The Hague — routing solar cooperative revenues to vulnerable households in Scheveningen and triggering a welfare policy change
excerpt: The Hague tested whether solar cooperative revenues from Slim Strandnet could be routed directly to people in need — reducing energy bills without requiring them to join a cooperative. Behind the experiment lies a larger vision: a city-wide social cooperative that ensures energy security and independence for everyone, regardless of whether they can afford a solar panel. Inside the design, the experiment, and what it takes to make the energy transition structurally just.
